summary: Lima is mentioned in the documents primarily as a location where CIA stations received classified messages and where an attack on a Cuban Embassy attache's house occurred. One classified message from December 2, 1963, was sent to CIA stations in Mexico City, Bogota, Lima, and Guatemala regarding GRACE HOLMES and a P.O. box in Coral Gables, Florida. Another document discusses an attack on a Cuban Embassy attache's house in Lima, Peru, in March 1977, and references coordination of United Revolutionary Organizations. The FBI document directs the Bureau to contact the CIA and DIA for more details, as the American Embassy did not submit a report. The documents suggest Lima was a point of communication for CIA activities and a site of anti-Cuban activity.
significance: Lima's significance in the JFK context is indirect. It appears as a location where CIA communications related to Grace Holmes were directed shortly after the assassination. It also appears as a location of anti-Cuban activity, which is relevant given the theories surrounding Cuban involvement in the assassination. However, the documents do not directly link Lima to the assassination itself.
